meanings.definition: To pull or pick off or out quickly
meanings.sent1: She had to pluck the flower from the garden.
meanings.sent2: The chef needed to pluck the feathers from the chicken.
meanings.sent3: He tried to pluck the idea from his mind like a stubborn weed.
meanings.sent4: The magician seemed to pluck the rabbit out of thin air.
meanings.sent5: The wind plucked the hat from her head and carried it away.

meanings.definition: To pull at or remove with a sudden movement
meanings.sent1: The child tried to pluck the toy from the shelf.
meanings.sent2: She plucked the pen from his hand before he could write.
meanings.sent3: The cat tried to pluck the toy mouse from under the couch.
meanings.sent4: The storm plucked the leaves from the trees with great force.
meanings.sent5: The bird plucked the worm from the ground and flew away.

meanings.definition: To play (a stringed instrument) by plucking the strings with the fingers
meanings.sent1: He learned to pluck the guitar strings with ease.
meanings.sent2: She plucked the harp strings gently, creating a soothing melody.
meanings.sent3: The musician tried to pluck the strings faster than ever before.
meanings.sent4: The sound of the violin plucking the heartstrings echoed in the hall.
meanings.sent5: The banjo player plucked the strings with incredible speed and skill.

meanings.definition: Spirited and determined courage or resourcefulness
meanings.sent1: Her pluck in the face of danger inspired others around her.
meanings.sent2: The team showed great pluck in their efforts to win the game.
meanings.sent3: His pluck in trying times earned him the respect of his peers.
meanings.sent4: The pluck of the underdog team surprised everyone with their victory.
meanings.sent5: The explorer's pluck in the face of adversity led to new discoveries.
